bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to James Carroll, August 16, 1906

div1.p: Kean informs Carroll that efforts are being made for Carroll to receive some substantial recognition for his services with the Yellow Fever Commission. Included are notes by Truby. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to James Carroll, August 16, 1906
div1.opener:
Carroll
OFFICE OF SURGEON GENERAL
AUG 16
19928
Z 1906
WAR DEPARTMENT
OFFICE OF THE SURGEON GENERAL,
WASHINGTON.
August 16, 1906
19928
First Lieutenant James Carroll,
Assistant Surgeon, U. S. Army
Army Medical Museum Building,
Washington, D.C.
Sir:
div1.p:
I am directed by the Surgeon General to inform you that
The Military Secretary is in receipt of a letter from the Secre-
tary to the President asking him to invite the attention of the
Surgeon General to an editorial article in “The Outlook” for
August 11, 1906, entitled “The Republic's Forgetfulness”, and
asking for a report as to whether there cannot be some action
taken as suggested in such article.

The Surgeon General thinks that, as the most prominent and
meritorious surviving member of the board concerning the demon-
stration of the method of transmission of yellow fever, and as
the first volunteer to submit to experimental inoculation, you
should receive some substantial recognition of your services,
and desires to make such recommendation to the President. He
would like, therefore, a careful and detailed report showing
clearly your connection with this work and the share taken by you
in its discovery. Should you desire to submit them, extracts
from reports and documents bearing on the question may be submitted
with it, or reference made to them.
div1.closer:
Very respectfully, J R Kean → Major. Surgeon, U. S. Army.
I think that Carroll in Aug 1906 would
